channel.title: Crowdfunding Collection #115, including every tabletop rpg project started between 08/04 and 08/18
channel.description:
I present to you the new [URL='https://teylen.blog/2019/08/19/crowdfunding-collection-115/'][B]Crowdfunding Collection #115, including every tabletop rpg project started between 08/04 and 08/18.[/B][/URL]. Which I will be posting more regularly :slight_smile:
After having been to the RatCon convention, there are no fewer than 66 projects. First I’d like to briefly address the two German language ones. [B]Dungeon Crawl Classic[/B] is being translated by System Matters and I am tempted; despite the artwork. Fans of The Dark Eye and Cthulhu should check out [B]Sandy Petersen’s Cthulhu Mythos für das Schwarze Auge[/B] which combines the unlikely pair. Onto the English projects, I am quite enticed by the Patreon of [B]Samjoko Publishing[/B] for creating the [B]Babel Magazine[/B]. The magazine offers English translations from tabletop rpgs from all over the world, an exciting endeavor, which got me to join the projects in the second I learned of it. If you like gm-less story games, you should have a look at [B]Dusk to Midnight[/B]. The game puts the players in the role of mech-soldiers doomed to be on the loosing side of a war, while not necessarily ending in tragedy. I consider the setting interesting, the zine-format as nifty and backed it. Another interesting setting, in my opinion, is offered by [B]Titans Trail[/B]. The combination of Mecha, Kajiu und Victoriana, basically putting Pacific Rim and Dowtown Abbey into a mixer does sound intriguing enough that I got an eye on it. In comparison the setting of [B]USAGI YOJIMBO[/B] is almost traditional. As traditional as a samurai tale with anthropomorphic animals can be. The setting is based on the Manga by the same name and the new edition does got fitted with the PbtA-engine. Which sounds quite cool. I haven’t read the „For the Crown and the Dragon“ novel by Stephen Hunt, sollten yet if you did – or like „weird historical fantasy“ – you might take a look at the [B]Crown and Dragon[/B] Kickstarter, which fits it with the Savage World system. [B]The Realm of the Gateway[/B] offers an original setting that spans and combines science fiction and fantasy covering various genres. If you are curious, you can check out the base rules on DTRPG. Back to a Story Game, [B]Collateral Damage[/B] puts you in the role of the side-characters in an action scenario. This can cover various genres, as long as there is action, and the main goal is to make it out alive. The game aims to provide a fast one-shot experience and does sound fascinating. There are as well two Break Kickstarter campaigns. [B]Carbyne Jungle[/B] has an interesting setting of mixing science fiction and fantasy while offering three distinctly different play modes that can still be utilized in one game with each other. Which sounds like quite a feat and spiked my interest. Then there’s [B]Broken![/B] which doesn’t have either a setting or a system, but lets backers vote on it via their pledges, which I find quite strange. Of course there are other projects, like the D&D sourcebooks [B]The Islands & Aswangs Book[/B], offering an insight into Filipino myth and folklore, and [B]Witchcraft: Magic of Hereva[/B], for the fans of the web comic. There are many cool sourcebooks to help you build your setting or city like [B]Magical Industrial Revolution[/B], [B]City Builder[/B] and [B]Maps: Buildings, Castles and Dungeons[/B]. Well, there are many more sourcebooks, adventures, dice and many many other projects, see for yourself:

I haven’t read the „For the Crown and the Dragon“ novel by Stephen Hunt, sollten yet if you did – or like „weird historical fantasy“ – you might take a look at the Crown and Dragon Kickstarter, which fits it with the Savage World system.
